content.description: Starts up on steep fun juggy rock that changes character and difficulty all to soon. Work out a couple of tricky sections to the even trickier crux. Immediately above the crux an initial easier section isn't as easy as it looks. Soon after, the climbing does get easier and leads to the choss corner crack but the jams are perfect hands . Continue up the crack to a point where one can move out left at a bolt. Sequential climbing up steeper rock leads to a nice stance and a 2 Mussy lower off
content.location: Center of the wall leading to a left facing corner crack

climbs.name: Sheep in Wolves' Clothing
climbs.fa: Marty Lewis, Jeff Scheuerell, Darrell Hensel, 1/2020

content.description: Slab climbing leads to a broken area, move left into a dihedral, turn a roof, finish on face.
content.location: Just left of the Megalithic approach dihedral.

content.description: Easy jug climbing to start, followed by off vertical face on good rock through it's crux section.  The rock is a little less quality higher, but should clean up.
content.location: Right of Megalithic.  There is now a dedicated belay at the start.

content.description: Not a great quality line but has an interesting/funky crux separated by crunchy, hollow flakes at the start and a big chossy flake/crack at the top.
content.location: The namesake of the cliff. Straight up from the right (lower) belay anchor.

content.description: If you like technical slabs...this is a great route! If not, you'll hate it and think it's the worst route in the gorge haha. Since less than vertical harder climbs are less frequent here, this rig is kinda stand out for the area in my opinion. After a cruiser start, you'll find 3 devious cruxes complete with glassy feet, a thin one finger pocket crimp, underclings, pinches, layaways...maybe a slab-dyno...and cerebral moves in between. You'll probably want your belayer to unclip the first draw after you clip the second bolt. Exciting but well protected.
content.location: First route left of Megalithic. Either start from the left (upper) bolted belay or the center bolted belay...

content.description:
Nice location on the Megalithic shield. Primarily an off-vertical slab.

From the DS belay anchor go up and slightly left instead of stepping right as for the DS start. Pass a hole and continue to a right leaning dihedral/offset. Follow this to the mussies.

As you look down at the bridge parts you may understand the name.
content.protection: 14 bolts (or 15 if starting at the Megalithic belay and passing the DS belay.) Mussy anchor.
